questions.question_text: What is the way to decide how a packet will move from an untrusted outside host to a protected inside that is behind a firewall, which permits the hacker to determine which ports are open and if the packets can pass through the packet-filtering of the firewall.

choices.D: The hacker failed to do banner grabbing as he didn't get the version of the Apache web server.
choices.B: The hacker successfully completed the banner grabbing.
choices.C: The hacker should've used nmap -O host.domain.com.
choices.A: nmap can't retrieve the version number of any running remote service.

questions.question_text:
An attacker tries to do banner grabbing on a remote web server and executes the following command.
//IMG//

Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at http://nmap.org/submit/.
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 6.42 seconds
What did the hacker accomplish?

discussion.content: VERY UNETHICAL to not telling uses at the beginning of the practice they they will be Locked up to pay!!! Now I have to go through a other we site reading again 36 page of questions and find new questions. If you would say it upfront I might of paid!
B is correct. You are wrong, the banner grabbing was successful but was changed by admin to not include the verison. -O is for os detection.
The correct answer is C. The attack should have used nmap -o host.domain.com. Without using the -O syntax, he failed to grab the version of Apache httpd and other possible details about the server.

questions.question_text:
Sid is a judge for a programming contest. Before the code reaches him it goes through a restricted OS and is tested there. If it passes, then it moves onto Sid.
What is this middle step called?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Option C is correct, Sandboxing the code
Option C is correct, Sandboxing the code
If fuzzy testing is right per the website then probably the middle steps takes place in a sandbox but what is done inside is the fuzzy testing that the question is looking for.

questions.question_text:
Cryptography is the practice and study of techniques for secure communication in the presence of third parties (called adversaries.) More generally, it is about constructing and analyzing protocols that overcome the influence of adversaries and that are related to various aspects in information security such as data confidentiality, data integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation. Modern cryptography intersects the disciplines of mathematics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of cryptography include ATM cards, computer passwords, and electronic commerce.
Basic example to understand how cryptography works is given below:
//IMG//

Which of the following choices is true about cryptography?

choices.D: Public-key cryptography, also known as asymmetric cryptography, public key is for decrypt, private key is for encrypt.
choices.C: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) use the asymmetric encryption both (public/private key pair) to deliver the shared session key and to achieve a communication way.
choices.A: Algorithm is not the secret, key is the secret.
choices.B: Symmetric-key algorithms are a class of algorithms for cryptography that use the different cryptographic keys for both encryption of plaintext and decryption of ciphertext.

discussion.content:

C makes more sense
